Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Explore the Theoretical Framework of Engineering Knowledge Transfer in Cybermanufacturing Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
3D Printing, also known as additive manufacturing, offers the potential for individuals and companies to design and produce customized parts in quantities as small as a single unit. However, unlike conventional mass production, for which production machines are adjusted to maintain quality by periodically measuring the parts that are produced, the small lots produced in 3D Printing do not provide the opportunity to tune the production machines in the same way. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will investigate a statistical method for adjusting the production quality of a 3D Printing machine based on experience in producing parts of different part types. Such a tool has the capability to be offered to manufacturers as a cloud-based utility, with possible extension to aggregating data from similar machines at different sites.

The fundamental barrier to knowledge transfer between engineering processes lies in lurking variables, which are process variables that are unobserved due to infeasibility of measurement or insufficient knowledge. The project will model and mitigate the effects of lurking variables in terms of observable control variables to enable a novel gray-box model transfer strategy for additive manufacturing systems. The proposed research tasks include: (1) establishing a theoretical formulation of effect equivalence to quantify effects of lurking variables, (2) exploring a statistical foundation for learning effect equivalence, (3) verifying effect equivalence models and their robustness, and (4) obtaining engineering insight from effect equivalence and developing a multi-resolution measurement strategy. The project is expected to produce a mathematical formulation of engineering effect equivalence, demonstrate the formulation in predicting geometric shape deformation of 3D products built by additive manufacturing machines, and a multi-resolution measurement strategy for equivalence-based additive manufacturing process control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manufacturing has become increasingly hyper-connected and accessible with the advancement of the industrial Internet of Things, and Cyber-Physical Systems as its backbone. Cybermanufacturing has recently been proposed as a future manufacturing paradigm with seamless integration of computing, manufacturing, and services. A new class of cybermanufacturing technologies with significant potential to fundamentally transform how people interact with manufacturing is the cyber-physical additive manufacturing system (CPAMS). The individual processes in such a system manufacture products from computer-aided design models by adding material layer by layer, enabling the direct fabrication of complex shapes and eliminating the bulk and waste associated with traditional manufacturing. The advantages offered by cybermanufacturing systems, and by a CPAMS in particular, can potentially inaugurate a revolutionary new era in manufacturing.

A critical issue with the high-confidence operation of cybermanufacturing systems, especially for a CPAMS, is quality control of the interconnected and distributed manufacturing environments. A consequence of the enormous differences among product designs/varieties, materials, processes, and user conditions in the environments is that a control policy established in one process is not directly applicable to others. In a CPAMS, machine-to-machine variations within the same type of additive manufacturing (AM) technology diminish the capability of the distributed system to mobilize all machines for accelerated volume production. The success of a localized and isolated quality control service that result from these features relies on user expertise, which inevitably limits the accessibility and connectivity of cybermanufacturing due to knowledge disparity, and results in increased system lead-time and operation costs. This leads to the following important question, which was the focus of this project: how can we transfer engineering knowledge and quality control procedures across manufacturing environments in a cybermanufacturing system to enable their high-confidence and high-efficiency operations?

Our joint collaborative research with the University of Southern California, Northwestern University, and Florida State University has provided a framework, and associated statistical methodology and algorithms, for knowledge transfer in cybermanufacturing systems. The framework was formulated using the equivalent effects of lurking variables of the manufacturing environments in terms of control variables whose effects are more easily understood and modeled. This framework has three components: (a) formulating model transfer via a function that benchmarks a lurking variable’s effect on a new process in terms of a control variable’s effect under a prior process, (b) establishing a statistical methodology to learn the function based on data from the new process, and data and a model from the prior process, and (c) incorporating the learned function into the model for the prior process, thereby completing its transfer to the new process. The framework and methodology/algorithms established by our research team enable straightforward and efficient model transfer across different AM processes in a CPAMS. Furthermore, learning the equivalent effects of a lurking variable in terms of a control variable facilitates one’s understanding of changes in lurking variables in a CPAMS. These facts were demonstrated by two case studies for in-plane shape deviation model transfer across stereolithography processes. In these case studies, we uncovered the effects of lurking overexposure and calibration changes in the process in terms of the equivalent effects of compensation, which led to more interpretable deviation models.

This framework also paved the way for our construction of a sequential quality control algorithm for cybermanufacturing systems based on corrections to control variables that are derived from the equivalent effects of lurking variables. We proved that, under fairly general conditions on a cybermanufacturing system, this algorithm can converge to the optimum quality control policy for a new process using the model for a prior process. The sequential algorithm has been shown in simulation studies of a stereolithography process to construct satisfactory quality control policies in a simple fashion after a few iterations.

Ultimately, the results of our research from studies on CPAMS data and simulations indicate that the outcomes of this project can advance comprehensive quality control for cybermanufacturing systems, and consequently contribute to smarter cybermanufacturing systems.

There have been extensive and productive collaborations among the PIs from Purdue, the University of Southern California, and Northwestern University. The project provided opportunities for interdisciplinary training of PhD students due to the collaborative research among the PIs. One doctoral student has benefited from this project, in that the student wrote two papers (which will form parts of the student’s thesis dissertation) motivated by this project. The research outcomes have been disseminated nationally. Specifically, a paper describing our framework and learning methodology for model transfer, and containing real-life case studies, has been accepted for publication in The Annals of Applied Statistics. The results of this research have been presented at multiple conferences, workshops, and seminar series.
